question_details.query: What actions can be taken to mitigate the impacts of roads on amphibian populations?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Several actions to mitigate the impacts of roads on amphibian populations have been studied. Two studies in Germany found that closing roads during seasonal amphibian migration protected large numbers of amphibians from death [842]. Six out of seven studies in several countries, including Canada, Germany, and the USA, showed that installing culverts or tunnels significantly reduced amphibian road deaths [884]. However, one study found that this was only effective when barrier fencing was also installed [884]. The use of these crossings by amphibians is supported by 15 of 24 studies, which found that 23-100% of culverts or tunnels were used by amphibians [884]. The effectiveness and use of these crossings can be influenced by their design, including diameter, length, lighting, and substrate [884]. Some culvert designs, such as those with one-way tunnels and vertical entry chutes, were found to be unsuitable and resulted in high mortality rates [884]. One study also noted that despite the installation of culverts, thousands of amphibians were still killed on the road [884]. Human assistance for migrating amphibians has also been studied. Despite efforts to move large numbers of amphibians across roads, two studies in Italy and the UK observed population declines of 64-70% over 6-10 years in toad populations that were being assisted [784]. In the UK, one study found that over 500 toads were still killed on roads at 7% of sites with human assistance patrols [784].
summary_statements: Studies have examined several actions to mitigate the impacts of roads on amphibian populations.
Two studies in Germany found that closing roads during seasonal amphibian migration protected large numbers of amphibians from death.
Studies in several countries, including Canada, Germany, and the USA, showed that installing culverts or tunnels significantly reduced amphibian road deaths.
One study found that installing culverts or tunnels was only effective at reducing amphibian road deaths when barrier fencing was also installed.
Multiple studies found that 23-100% of culverts or tunnels were used by amphibians.
The effectiveness and use of amphibian crossings can be influenced by their design, including diameter, length, lighting, and substrate.
Some culvert designs, such as those with one-way tunnels and vertical entry chutes, were found to be unsuitable and resulted in high mortality rates for amphibians.
One study noted that despite the installation of culverts, thousands of amphibians were still killed on the road.
Human assistance for migrating amphibians has been studied.
Despite efforts to move large numbers of amphibians across roads, two studies in Italy and the UK observed population declines of 64-70% over 6-10 years in assisted toad populations.
In the UK, one study found that over 500 toads were still killed on roads at 7% of sites that had human assistance patrols.

question_details.query: How do different partial harvesting methods in USA forests compare to clearcutting in their impact on salamander populations?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
A meta-analysis of 24 studies in North America indicated that partial harvesting, which encompasses methods like harvesting groups of trees, shelterwood harvesting, and thinning, resulted in smaller reductions in salamander populations compared to clearcutting (844, 851, 852).

When compared to clearcutting, three studies in the USA on harvesting trees in small groups did not find a higher abundance of amphibians or salamanders (844). For shelterwood harvesting, three studies in the USA found that it led to higher, similar, or initially higher and then similar salamander abundance in comparison to clearcutting (851). In the case of thinning, two of four studies in the USA discovered higher amphibian abundance or a less negative overall response in thinned forests, while the other two studies had mixed results depending on the species and time since harvest (852). One study found that emigrating salamanders used thinned forests significantly more than clearcuts (852).

In contrast to unharvested areas, harvesting trees in small groups was found in two US studies to significantly decrease salamander abundance and alter species composition (844). Similarly, two out of three US studies showed that shelterwood harvesting also decreased salamander abundance and changed the composition of species when compared to areas with no harvesting (851). Studies on thinning compared to unharvested forests have shown mixed effects, with some species' abundance increasing while others, like the ensatina salamanders, decreased (852). Another study noted a negative overall response of amphibians to thinning, although one study found that a high volume of pre-existing downed wood helped prevent population declines after thinning (852).
summary_statements: A meta-analysis of 24 studies in North America indicated that partial harvesting resulted in smaller reductions in salamander populations compared to clearcutting.
Partial harvesting encompasses methods like harvesting groups of trees, shelterwood harvesting, and thinning.
When compared to clearcutting, three studies in the USA on harvesting trees in small groups did not find a higher abundance of amphibians or salamanders.
Three studies in the USA found that shelterwood harvesting led to higher, similar, or initially higher and then similar salamander abundance in comparison to clearcutting.
In the case of thinning, two of four studies in the USA discovered higher amphibian abundance or a less negative overall response in thinned forests compared to clearcut forests.
The other two of four studies in the USA on thinning had mixed results for amphibian abundance depending on the species and time since harvest.
One study found that emigrating salamanders used thinned forests significantly more than the salamanders used clearcuts.
In contrast to unharvested areas, two US studies found that harvesting trees in small groups significantly decreased salamander abundance.
In contrast to unharvested areas, two US studies found that harvesting trees in small groups altered salamander species composition.
Two out of three US studies showed that shelterwood harvesting decreased salamander abundance when compared to areas with no harvesting.
Two out of three US studies showed that shelterwood harvesting changed the composition of salamander species when compared to areas with no harvesting.
Studies on thinning compared to unharvested forests have shown mixed effects on salamander populations.
When comparing thinned to unharvested forests, the abundance of some salamander species increased while the abundance of others, like the ensatina salamanders, decreased.
One study noted a negative overall response of amphibians to forest thinning.
One study found that a high volume of pre-existing downed wood helped prevent amphibian population declines after forest thinning.

question_details.query: What are the potential benefits and harms of controlling fish populations to protect amphibians?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Studies have found that controlling fish populations can have both benefits and harms for amphibians. One review in Australia, the UK and USA found that fish control, which included using rotenone, increased breeding success for four amphibian species (828). Three studies in Sweden, the UK and USA found that eliminating fish using rotenone increased numbers of amphibian species, abundance, and recruitment of newt populations (828). However, the use of rotenone can also have negative effects. Two replicated studies in Pakistan and the UK found that when rotenone was applied, many frogs died and a small number of newts showed symptoms of negative effects (828). An alternative to rotenone, a controlled study in Mexico, found that excluding fish using a barrier increased weight gain of axolotls (829).
summary_statements: Studies have found that controlling fish populations can have both benefits and harms for amphibians.
A review in Australia, the UK and USA found that fish control, which included using rotenone, increased breeding success for four amphibian species.
Three studies in Sweden, the UK and USA found that eliminating fish using rotenone increased numbers of amphibian species.
Three studies in Sweden, the UK and USA found that eliminating fish using rotenone increased amphibian abundance.
Three studies in Sweden, the UK and USA found that eliminating fish using rotenone increased recruitment of newt populations.
The use of rotenone can have negative effects.
Two replicated studies in Pakistan and the UK found that when rotenone was applied, many frogs died.
Two replicated studies in Pakistan and the UK found that when rotenone was applied, a small number of newts showed symptoms of negative effects.
A controlled study in Mexico found that excluding fish using a barrier increased weight gain of axolotls.
Excluding fish using a barrier is an alternative to using rotenone.

question_details.query: What is the evidence for the effectiveness of engaging the public in amphibian conservation efforts in Europe and the USA?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Five studies in Canada, the UK and USA found that amphibian data collection projects engaged 100–10,506 volunteers and were active in 16–17 states in the USA [760]. Five studies in the UK and USA found that volunteers undertook 412 surveys, surveyed 121–7,872 sites, swabbed almost 6,000 amphibians and submitted thousands of amphibian records [760].Two before-and-after studies in Estonia and Taiwan found that habitat management with participation of volunteers increased natterjack toad and Taipei frog populations [777]. One controlled study in Mexico found that engaging landowners in aquatic habitat management increased axolotl weight [777]. Six studies in Estonia, the USA and UK found that between eight and 41,000 volunteers were engaged in aquatic and terrestrial habitat restoration programmes for amphibians [777]. Individual programmes restored up to 1,023 ponds or over 11,500 km2 of habitat [777].Two studies in Estonia and the UK found that raising public awareness, along with other interventions, increased numbers of natterjack toads and created 1,023 ponds for amphibians [831]. One before-and-after study in Mexico found that raising awareness in tourists, increased their knowledge of axolotls [831]. One study in Taiwan found that holding press conferences to publicize frog conservation had no effect on a green tree frog project [831]. Two studies in Panama and the UK found that awareness campaigns reached over 50,000 members of the public each year or trained 1,016 people at 57 events over four years [831].
summary_statements: Five studies in Canada, the UK and USA found that amphibian data collection projects engaged between 100 and 10,506 volunteers.
Amphibian data collection projects were active in 16–17 states in the USA.
Five studies in the UK and USA found that volunteers undertook 412 surveys.
According to five studies in the UK and USA, volunteers surveyed between 121 and 7,872 sites.
Volunteers swabbed almost 6,000 amphibians according to five studies in the UK and USA.
Five studies in the UK and USA found that volunteers submitted thousands of amphibian records.
Two before-and-after studies in Estonia and Taiwan found that habitat management with volunteer participation increased natterjack toad populations.
Two before-and-after studies in Estonia and Taiwan found that habitat management with volunteer participation increased Taipei frog populations.
One controlled study in Mexico found that engaging landowners in aquatic habitat management increased axolotl weight.
Six studies in Estonia, the USA and UK found that between eight and 41,000 volunteers were engaged in aquatic and terrestrial habitat restoration programmes for amphibians.
Individual habitat restoration programmes restored up to 1,023 ponds.
Individual habitat restoration programmes restored over 11,500 km2 of habitat.
Two studies in Estonia and the UK found that raising public awareness, along with other interventions, increased numbers of natterjack toads.
Raising public awareness, along with other interventions, created 1,023 ponds for amphibians according to two studies in Estonia and the UK.
One before-and-after study in Mexico found that raising awareness in tourists increased the tourists' knowledge of axolotls.
One study in Taiwan found that holding press conferences to publicize frog conservation had no effect on a green tree frog project.
Two studies in Panama and the UK found that awareness campaigns reached over 50,000 members of the public each year.
Two studies in Panama and the UK found that awareness campaigns trained 1,016 people at 57 events over four years.

question_details.query: What are the overall success rates for establishing new amphibian populations through translocation or the release of captive-bred individuals?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Three global reviews and one replicated, before-and-after study in the USA found that 35 of 54 (65%) amphibian translocations resulted in established breeding populations or substantial recruitment to the adult population [854]. An additional two translocations led to breeding, and one resulted in survival after release [854]. A review indicated that translocations involving over 1,000 animals had a higher success rate, and this success was not influenced by the animal source (wild or captive), life stage, continent, or the reason for the translocation [854].
summary_statements: Three global reviews and one replicated, before-and-after study in the USA found that 35 of 54 (65%) amphibian translocations resulted in established breeding populations or substantial recruitment to the adult population.
An additional two amphibian translocations led to breeding.
One amphibian translocation resulted in survival after release.
A review indicated that translocations involving over 1,000 animals had a higher success rate.
The success of amphibian translocations involving over 1,000 animals was not influenced by the animal source (wild or captive), life stage, continent, or the reason for the translocation.

question_details.query: As an alternative to direct antifungal treatment of amphibians, what environmental management actions can reduce the threat of chytridiomycosis?

summary_details.relevant_summary: One environmental management action that can reduce the threat of chytridiomycosis in amphibians is temperature treatment [770]. Four out of five studies, including four replicated and controlled studies in Australia, Switzerland, and the USA, have shown that raising the enclosure or water temperature to a range of 30–37°C for over 16 hours can cure frogs and toads of the disease [770]. However, one study reported that a heat treatment at 30–35°C for 36 hours was not effective in curing northern leopard frogs [770].
summary_statements: Temperature treatment is one environmental management action that can reduce the threat of chytridiomycosis in amphibians.
Raising the enclosure or water temperature to a range of 30–37°C for over 16 hours can cure frogs and toads of chytridiomycosis.
A heat treatment at 30–35°C for 36 hours was not effective in curing northern leopard frogs.

question_details.query: When managing understory vegetation in US forests, how does the effectiveness of herbicide use compare to mechanical removal for amphibian populations?

summary_details.relevant_summary: One randomized, replicated, controlled study in the USA found that numbers of amphibian species, but not abundance, were significantly higher in plots with mechanical understory reduction compared to those without [781]. In comparison, one replicated, randomized, controlled, before-and-after study in the USA found that areas where vegetation was treated with herbicides had similar richness of combined reptile and amphibian species compared to areas not treated with herbicide [3712].
summary_statements: A study in the USA found that numbers of amphibian species were significantly higher in plots with mechanical understory reduction compared to plots without the reduction.
A study in the USA found that amphibian abundance was not significantly higher in plots with mechanical understory reduction compared to plots without the reduction.
A study in the USA found that areas where vegetation was treated with herbicides had similar richness of combined reptile and amphibian species compared to areas not treated with herbicide.

question_details.query: What does the evidence suggest about the effectiveness of legal and regulatory frameworks, such as species protection laws or financial incentive schemes, for amphibian conservation?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Three reviews in the Netherlands and UK found that legal protection of amphibian species was not effective at protecting populations during development [779]. Two reviews in the UK found that the number of great crested newt mitigation licences issued over 10 years increased to over 600 in England and Wales [779]. One review found that legislation to reduce trade in two frog species resulted in the recovery of the over-exploited populations [785, 824]. One study in South Africa found that the number of permits issued for scientific and educational use of amphibians increased from 1987 to 1990 [785].
summary_statements: Three reviews in the Netherlands and UK found that legal protection of amphibian species was not effective at protecting populations during development.
Two reviews in the UK found that the number of great crested newt mitigation licences issued over 10 years increased to over 600 in England and Wales.
One review found that legislation to reduce trade in two frog species resulted in the recovery of the over-exploited populations.
One study in South Africa found that the number of permits issued for scientific and educational use of amphibians increased from 1987 to 1990.

question_details.query: What are the documented benefits and negative impacts of livestock grazing on agricultural lands for amphibian habitats and populations?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Five studies in Denmark, Estonia, and the UK found that habitat management that included the reintroduction of grazing increased green toad populations and maintained or increased natterjack and common toad populations (780). Two studies in the USA found that the abundance of green frogs and/or American toads was higher with grazing (746), and one replicated site comparison study in the USA found that ungrazed sites had fewer bog turtles than grazed sites (3512). However, one replicated, controlled study in the UK found that grazed plots had a lower abundance of common toads and did not have a higher abundance of natterjack toads than ungrazed plots (780). Additionally, a before-and-after study in the UK found that pond restoration that included livestock exclusion increased pond use by breeding natterjack toads (746). 

Several studies found no significant difference between grazed and ungrazed areas. Three replicated, site comparison studies in the USA found that excluding livestock from streams or ponds did not increase the number of amphibian species or overall abundance, but did increase larval abundance and the abundance of green frog metamorphs (746). One randomized, replicated, controlled, before-and-after study in the USA found that excluding cattle from ponds did not increase the number of eggs or larval survival of Columbia spotted frogs (746). A replicated, randomized, controlled study in Australia found that ungrazed areas had similar overall reptile and amphibian abundance compared to those that were grazed (3512). One before-and-after study in the USA found that the decline in amphibian species was similar under both traditional season-long and intensive-early cattle stocking (780).
summary_statements: Five studies in Denmark, Estonia, and the UK found that habitat management that included the reintroduction of grazing increased green toad populations.
Five studies in Denmark, Estonia, and the UK found that habitat management that included the reintroduction of grazing maintained or increased natterjack and common toad populations.
Two studies in the USA found that the abundance of green frogs and/or American toads was higher with grazing.
One replicated site comparison study in the USA found that ungrazed sites had fewer bog turtles than grazed sites.
One replicated, controlled study in the UK found that grazed plots had a lower abundance of common toads than ungrazed plots.
One replicated, controlled study in the UK found that grazed plots did not have a higher abundance of natterjack toads than ungrazed plots.
A before-and-after study in the UK found that pond restoration that included livestock exclusion increased pond use by breeding natterjack toads.
Three replicated, site comparison studies in the USA found that excluding livestock from streams or ponds did not increase the number of amphibian species or the overall amphibian abundance.
Three replicated, site comparison studies in the USA found that excluding livestock from streams or ponds did increase larval abundance and the abundance of green frog metamorphs.
One randomized, replicated, controlled, before-and-after study in the USA found that excluding cattle from ponds did not increase the number of eggs or larval survival of Columbia spotted frogs.
A replicated, randomized, controlled study in Australia found that ungrazed areas had similar overall reptile and amphibian abundance compared to areas that were grazed.
One before-and-after study in the USA found that the decline in amphibian species was similar under both traditional season-long and intensive-early cattle stocking.

question_details.query: What treatments are available for amphibians infected with chytridiomycosis and how effective are they?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Treatments available for amphibians infected with chytridiomycosis include antifungal treatments, temperature adjustments, and a combination of fungicide and pond drying [767, 882, 770]. Twelve of sixteen studies found that antifungal treatments cured or increased the survival of amphibians with chytridiomycosis [882]. Specifically, treatment with itraconazole was found to be effective in six of eight studies [882]. However, six studies also reported that certain fungicides could lead to death or other negative side effects in amphibians [882]. Another treatment option is temperature adjustment. Four of five studies found that raising the enclosure or water temperature to 30-37°C for over 16 hours cured frogs and toads of the infection [770]. However, one study on northern leopard frogs did not find this heat treatment to be effective [770]. In a study on wild midwife toads in Mallorca, treating them with a fungicide along with pond drying reduced infection levels but did not eradicate the disease [767].
summary_statements: Treatments available for amphibians infected with chytridiomycosis include antifungal treatments, temperature adjustments, and a combination of fungicide and pond drying.
Twelve of sixteen studies found that antifungal treatments cured or increased the survival of amphibians with chytridiomycosis.
Treatment with itraconazole was found to be effective in six of eight studies for treating chytridiomycosis.
Six studies reported that certain fungicides could lead to death or other negative side effects in amphibians.
Temperature adjustment is another treatment option for chytridiomycosis.
Four of five studies found that raising the enclosure or water temperature to 30-37°C for over 16 hours cured frogs and toads of chytridiomycosis infection.
One study on northern leopard frogs did not find heat treatment to be effective against chytridiomycosis.
In a study on wild midwife toads in Mallorca, treating the toads with a fungicide along with pond drying reduced infection levels.
In a study on wild midwife toads in Mallorca, treating the toads with a fungicide along with pond drying did not eradicate chytridiomycosis.

question_details.query: For amphibian conservation in North America, how do the outcomes of creating new wetlands compare to restoring existing wetlands?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
When creating new wetlands for amphibians in the USA, studies have found mixed results when compared to natural wetlands, with some created wetlands having similar amphibian species numbers and abundance, while others have fewer species or lower abundance (880). The success of created wetlands is influenced by factors such as wetland design, vegetation, water levels, surrounding habitat, the presence of fish, and the distance to source wetlands (880). Furthermore, some studies in the USA indicated that certain amphibian species were exclusively found in either created or natural wetlands (880).

One study in the USA that looked at both created and restored wetlands found that together they had amphibian species numbers and abundance that were higher than or similar to natural wetlands (880). Another study in the USA also found that created, restored, enhanced, and natural wetlands had similar combined reptile and amphibian species richness (3755). However, a separate before-and-after site comparison in the USA noted that a restored wetland exhibited lower reptile species richness and diversity than an undisturbed wetland (3755).
summary_statements: When creating new wetlands for amphibians in the USA, studies have found mixed results when compared to natural wetlands.
Some created wetlands have amphibian species numbers and abundance that are similar to natural wetlands.
Some created wetlands have fewer species or lower abundance of amphibians than natural wetlands.
The success of created wetlands is influenced by factors such as wetland design, vegetation, water levels, surrounding habitat, the presence of fish, and the distance to source wetlands.
Some studies in the USA indicated that certain amphibian species were exclusively found in either created or natural wetlands.

One study in the USA that looked at both created and restored wetlands found that together the wetlands had amphibian species numbers and abundance that were higher than or similar to natural wetlands.
A study in the USA found that created, restored, enhanced, and natural wetlands had similar combined reptile and amphibian species richness.
A separate before-and-after site comparison in the USA noted that a restored wetland exhibited lower reptile species richness and diversity than an undisturbed wetland.

question_details.query: What are the documented impacts of using prescribed fire on amphibian populations in US forest and grassland habitats?

summary_details.relevant_summary: The impacts of prescribed fire on amphibian populations are varied. Eight of fourteen studies in Australia, North America, and the USA found no effect of prescribed forest fires on amphibian abundance or the number of species (877). Four studies found mixed effects on amphibian abundance depending on the species, year, or season of the burn (877). Three studies found that fires increased amphibian abundance or the number of species, while one study found that abundance decreased with fires (877). Two studies in the USA found that the number of amphibian species and their abundance either increased or decreased with time since the prescribed forest fires (877). One before-and-after study in the USA found that spotted salamander hatching success increased following a prescribed forest fire (877). In a study on wetlands, burned areas had a similar abundance of reptiles and amphibians compared to unburned areas (3652). Additionally, one study found that burned areas had higher combined reptile and amphibian species richness than unburned areas, while another found the richness and diversity to be similar to that of unburned areas (3646). In areas where burning was used in combination with grazing, the overall reptile and amphibian abundance was similar to areas that were only burned or were unmanaged (3657).
summary_statements: The impacts of prescribed fire on amphibian populations are varied.
Eight of fourteen studies in Australia, North America, and the USA found no effect of prescribed forest fires on amphibian abundance or the number of species.
Four studies found mixed effects on amphibian abundance depending on the species, year, or season of the burn.
Three studies found that fires increased amphibian abundance or the number of species.
One study found that amphibian abundance decreased with fires.
Two studies in the USA found that the number of amphibian species and amphibian abundance either increased or decreased with time since the prescribed forest fires.
One before-and-after study in the USA found that spotted salamander hatching success increased following a prescribed forest fire.
In a study on wetlands, burned areas had a similar abundance of reptiles and amphibians compared to unburned areas.
One study found that burned areas had higher combined reptile and amphibian species richness than unburned areas.
Another study found the combined reptile and amphibian richness and diversity to be similar to that of unburned areas.
In areas where burning was used in combination with grazing, the overall reptile and amphibian abundance was similar to areas that were only burned or were unmanaged.

question_details.query: What is the state of evidence on the effectiveness of removing various types of invasive predators to benefit native amphibians?

summary_details.relevant_summary: One before-and-after study in the USA found that the abundance of squirrel tree frogs and green tree frogs increased after removal of invasive Cuban tree frogs (822). A replicated, before-and-after study in the USA found that removing American bullfrogs significantly increased a population of California red-legged frogs (825). Another study in the USA and Mexico found that eradicating bullfrogs from an area increased the range of leopard frogs (825). The same study found that after bullfrog removal, California red-legged frogs were found out in the open twice as frequently (825). One controlled study in New Zealand found that controlling rats had no significant effect on numbers of Hochstetter’s frog (839). However, another controlled study in New Zealand found that survival of Maud Island frogs was significantly higher in a predator-proof enclosure than in the wild (839). A third study in New Zealand found that at 58% of translocated Hamilton's frogs survived the first year within a predator-proof enclosure (839).
summary_statements: A before-and-after study in the USA found that the abundance of squirrel tree frogs and green tree frogs increased after removal of invasive Cuban tree frogs.
A replicated, before-and-after study in the USA found that removing American bullfrogs significantly increased a population of California red-legged frogs.
A study in the USA and Mexico found that eradicating bullfrogs from an area increased the range of leopard frogs.
A study in the USA and Mexico found that after bullfrog removal, California red-legged frogs were found out in the open twice as frequently.
A controlled study in New Zealand found that controlling rats had no significant effect on numbers of Hochstetter’s frog.
A controlled study in New Zealand found that survival of Maud Island frogs was significantly higher in a predator-proof enclosure than in the wild.
A study in New Zealand found that 58% of translocated Hamilton's frogs survived the first year within a predator-proof enclosure.

question_details.query: How does the success of reintroduction programs using captive-bred amphibians differ for Mallorcan midwife toads in Mallorca compared to green and golden bell frogs in Australia?

summary_details.relevant_summary: In Mallorca, captive-bred Mallorcan midwife toads released as tadpoles, toadlets, or adults established breeding populations at 38% to 100% of sites (873). One study in the UK found that while predator defenses were maintained in a reintroduced captive-bred population, genetic diversity was reduced (873). Captive-bred Mallorcan midwife toads have been successfully raised to metamorphs or toadlets, with one UK study showing an 85% survival rate to metamorphosis (837). However, long-term captive breeding of this species (nine or more generations) has been associated with slower tadpole development, a reduction in one predator defense trait, and decreased genetic diversity (837). In contrast, reintroduction programs for the green and golden bell frog in Australia have had less success. Studies found that captive-bred green and golden bell frogs, released mainly as tadpoles, either did not establish breeding populations or only established them in one out of four release programs (872). Some captive-bred green and golden bell frogs released as tadpoles were found to have survived for at least 13 months after release (872). Other studies in Australia showed that a high proportion of captive-bred frogs released as eggs survived to metamorphosis, and there was limited breeding by released frogs (870). Additionally, the removal of viperine snakes in Mallorca led to an increase in the number of Mallorcan midwife toad larvae (830), and the addition of salt to a pond in Australia helped a population of green and golden bell frogs remain free of chytridiomycosis for at least six months (762).
summary_statements: In Mallorca, captive-bred Mallorcan midwife toads released as tadpoles, toadlets, or adults established breeding populations at 38% to 100% of sites.
One study in the UK found that predator defenses were maintained in a reintroduced captive-bred population of Mallorcan midwife toads.
One study in the UK found that the genetic diversity of a reintroduced captive-bred population of Mallorcan midwife toads was reduced.
Captive-bred Mallorcan midwife toads have been successfully raised to metamorphs or toadlets.
One UK study showed an 85% survival rate to metamorphosis for captive-bred Mallorcan midwife toads.
Long-term captive breeding of the Mallorcan midwife toad for nine or more generations has been associated with slower tadpole development.
Long-term captive breeding of the Mallorcan midwife toad for nine or more generations has been associated with a reduction in one predator defense trait.
Long-term captive breeding of the Mallorcan midwife toad for nine or more generations has been associated with decreased genetic diversity.
Reintroduction programs for the green and golden bell frog in Australia have had less success.
Studies found that captive-bred green and golden bell frogs, released mainly as tadpoles, either did not establish breeding populations or only established them in one out of four release programs.
Some captive-bred green and golden bell frogs released as tadpoles were found to have survived for at least 13 months after release.
Other studies in Australia showed that a high proportion of captive-bred green and golden bell frogs released as eggs survived to metamorphosis.
Other studies in Australia showed there was limited breeding by released green and golden bell frogs.
The removal of viperine snakes in Mallorca led to an increase in the number of Mallorcan midwife toad larvae.
The addition of salt to a pond in Australia helped a population of green and golden bell frogs remain free of chytridiomycosis for at least six months.

question_details.query: In Australian captive breeding programs, how do artificial fertilization and hormone treatments compare in their success and challenges for frogs?

summary_details.relevant_summary: In Australia, hormone treatment of male amphibians has been found to stimulate or increase sperm production, or result in successful captive breeding (883). For female amphibians in Australia, hormone treatment has had mixed results, with 30-71% of females producing viable eggs (883). The success of hormone treatment on female amphibians can also be dependent on the combination, amount or number of doses of hormones (883). Eggs that have been induced by hormone treatment have been raised successfully to tadpoles and froglets in captivity (883). One Australian study found that tadpole development in captivity was affected by parental care, density or temperature (835).
summary_statements: In Australia, hormone treatment of male amphibians has been found to stimulate or increase sperm production.
In Australia, hormone treatment of male amphibians has resulted in successful captive breeding.
For female amphibians in Australia, hormone treatment has had mixed results.
In Australia, 30-71% of female amphibians produce viable eggs following hormone treatment.
The success of hormone treatment on female amphibians can be dependent on the combination, amount or number of doses of hormones.
Eggs that have been induced by hormone treatment have been raised successfully to tadpoles and froglets in captivity.
One Australian study found that tadpole development in captivity was affected by parental care.
One Australian study found that tadpole development in captivity was affected by density.
One Australian study found that tadpole development in captivity was affected by temperature.

question_details.query: As an alternative to creating new ponds, what species augmentation techniques can be used to establish or increase amphibian populations at a site?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Three global reviews and one replicated, before-and-after study in the USA found that 35 of 54 (65%) amphibian translocations that could be assessed resulted in established breeding populations or substantial recruitment to the adult population [854]. Translocations of over 1,000 animals were found to be more successful in one review, which also found that success was not related to the source of the animals (wild or captive), their life-stage, the continent, or the reason for the translocation [854].

Twenty-two studies have examined the practice of head-starting amphibians from eggs for release [881]. Six of these ten studies, which included five replicated studies in Denmark, Spain, the UK, and the USA, along with a global review, found that releasing head-started tadpoles, metamorphs, or juveniles led to the establishment of breeding frog populations or an increase in the populations of frogs or toads [881]. Two other studies showed mixed results, with breeding populations established in 12 of 17 studies reviewed or at two of four sites [881]. Conversely, two studies found that head-started metamorphs or adults did not prevent a frog population decline or establish a breeding toad population [881]. For five of these studies, other interventions like the release of captive-bred individuals, translocation, or habitat management were also implemented [881]. Nine of ten studies, including nine replicated studies in Australia, Canada, Europe, and the USA, reported that head-started amphibians released as tadpoles, metamorphs, or adults successfully metamorphosed, tended to survive the first season, winter, or year, or bred successfully [881]. However, one study found adult survival was 1–17% over four years, and another reported limited breeding after the release of adults [881]. Four replicated studies in Australia, the UK, and the USA discovered that frog survival to metamorphosis and size at metamorphosis were greater, and the time to metamorphosis was shorter in head-started animals compared to their wild counterparts [881]. In contrast, one replicated study in Canada found that young head-started leopard frogs were smaller than those in the wild [881].
summary_statements: Three global reviews and one replicated, before-and-after study in the USA found that 65% of assessed amphibian translocations resulted in established breeding populations or substantial recruitment to the adult population.
One review found that translocations involving over 1,000 animals were more successful.
One review found that the success of amphibian translocation was not related to the source of the animals (wild or captive), their life-stage, the continent, or the reason for the translocation.
Twenty-two studies have examined the practice of head-starting amphibians from eggs for release.
Six studies found that releasing head-started tadpoles, metamorphs, or juveniles led to the establishment of breeding frog populations.
Six studies found that releasing head-started tadpoles, metamorphs, or juveniles led to an increase in the populations of frogs or toads.
Two other studies showed mixed results, with breeding populations established in 12 of 17 studies that were reviewed or at two of four sites.
Two studies found that head-started metamorphs or adults did not prevent a frog population decline.
Two studies found that head-started metamorphs or adults did not establish a breeding toad population.
For five studies on head-starting amphibians, other interventions like the release of captive-bred individuals, translocation, or habitat management were also implemented.
Nine of ten studies reported that head-started amphibians released as tadpoles, metamorphs, or adults successfully metamorphosed.
Nine of ten studies reported that head-started amphibians tended to survive the first season, winter, or year.
Nine of ten studies reported that head-started amphibians bred successfully.
One study found adult survival for head-started amphibians was 1–17% over four years.
Another study reported limited breeding after the release of head-started adults.
Four replicated studies discovered that frog survival to metamorphosis was greater in head-started animals compared to their wild counterparts.
Four replicated studies discovered that size at metamorphosis was greater in head-started animals compared to their wild counterparts.
Four replicated studies discovered that the time to metamorphosis was shorter in head-started animals compared to their wild counterparts.
One replicated study in Canada found that young head-started leopard frogs were smaller than those in the wild.

question_details.query: To protect migrating amphibians, how do physical interventions like tunnels and barrier fences compare to closing roads during migration seasons?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Two studies in Germany found that closing roads during breeding migrations protected large numbers of amphibians from death (842). This was the case at sites with only road closures and at sites that also had assisted crossings and barrier fences (842). Seven of eight studies found that installing barrier fencing along with culverts decreased amphibian road deaths (756). The effectiveness of these barriers can be dependent on the length and material of the fence (756). Some amphibians, such as treefrogs and 10% of common toads, were found to be able to climb over barrier fencing (756). For green frogs and leopard frogs, barriers of at least 0.6 m high were required to prevent them from climbing over (756). One study found that only a low number of amphibians were diverted by barriers (756). In six of seven studies, the installation of culverts or tunnels as road crossings was found to significantly decrease amphibian road deaths, although one of these studies noted this was only true when barrier fencing was also installed (884). One study found no effect on road deaths from installing culverts or tunnels (884). Fifteen of twenty-four studies found that culverts and tunnels were used by amphibians, however, five studies found that they were used by less than 10% of amphibians or not used at all (884). The use of culverts and tunnels by amphibians can be affected by their diameter, length, lighting, and substrate (884). Some culvert designs were found to be unsuitable for amphibians, and one study highlighted that thousands of amphibians were still killed on the road where tunnels were installed (884).
summary_statements: Closing roads during breeding migrations protected large numbers of amphibians from death.
Road closures protected amphibians at sites with only road closures and at sites that also had assisted crossings and barrier fences.
Installing barrier fencing along with culverts decreased amphibian road deaths.
The effectiveness of barrier fencing can be dependent on the length and material of the fence.
Some amphibians, such as treefrogs and 10% of common toads, were found to be able to climb over barrier fencing.
For green frogs and leopard frogs, barriers of at least 0.6 m high were required to prevent the frogs from climbing over.
Only a low number of amphibians were diverted by barriers in one study.
The installation of culverts or tunnels as road crossings was found to significantly decrease amphibian road deaths.
The decrease in amphibian deaths from culverts or tunnels was only true when barrier fencing was also installed in one study.
One study found no effect on road deaths from installing culverts or tunnels.
Culverts and tunnels were used by amphibians.
Five studies found that culverts and tunnels were used by less than 10% of amphibians or not used at all.
The use of culverts and tunnels by amphibians can be affected by the diameter, length, lighting, and substrate of the passages.
Some culvert designs were found to be unsuitable for amphibians.
Thousands of amphibians were still killed on the road where tunnels were installed.

question_details.query: What are the typical outcomes when creating new ponds to support toad populations in Europe?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Studies have shown that creating new ponds can support toad populations in Europe. In Germany, the UK, and the USA, translocated and naturally colonizing toads established breeding populations in 33% of created ponds in one study (868). In Denmark and Switzerland, 29-100% of created ponds were colonized by common and midwife toads (868). Captive-bred garlic toads, however, did not colonize newly created ponds (868). The creation and restoration of ponds, when combined with head-starting, led to an increase in European fire-bellied toad populations in Denmark (868). In Switzerland, midwife toads reproduced in 16% of created ponds (868). For green toads, pond creation along with other interventions was found to significantly increase their populations in Denmark (864). A study in Sweden showed that green toads used 59% of created ponds and reproduced in 41% of them (864). For natterjack toads in the UK and Denmark, pond creation with other interventions led to a significant increase in their populations, or maintained or increased them at 75% of sites (866). A UK study found that created ponds had lower tadpole mortality from desiccation but higher mortality from invertebrate predation when compared to natural ponds (866).
summary_statements: Creating new ponds can support toad populations in Europe.
In Germany, the UK, and the USA, translocated and naturally colonizing toads established breeding populations in 33% of created ponds.
In Denmark and Switzerland, 29-100% of created ponds were colonized by common and midwife toads.
Captive-bred garlic toads did not colonize newly created ponds.
The creation and restoration of ponds, when combined with head-starting, led to an increase in European fire-bellied toad populations in Denmark.
In Switzerland, midwife toads reproduced in 16% of created ponds.
Pond creation along with other interventions was found to significantly increase green toad populations in Denmark.
A study in Sweden showed that green toads used 59% of created ponds.
A study in Sweden showed that green toads reproduced in 41% of created ponds.
For natterjack toads in the UK and Denmark, pond creation with other interventions led to a significant increase in the toad populations.
For natterjack toads in the UK and Denmark, pond creation with other interventions maintained or increased the toad populations at 75% of sites.
A UK study found that created ponds had lower tadpole mortality from desiccation when compared to natural ponds.
A UK study found that created ponds had higher mortality from invertebrate predation when compared to natural ponds.

question_details.query: What are some alternatives to clearcutting forests, and what are their documented effects on amphibian populations?

summary_details.relevant_summary: One replicated study in Canada found that red-legged frogs showed no significant movement toward retained tree patches, but larger patches were selected more and moved out of less than small patches [847]. Two replicated, controlled studies in the USA and Indonesia found that the removal of coarse woody debris from standing forest did not decrease amphibian diversity or overall amphibian abundance, but did reduce species richness in one study [843]. Two replicated, controlled studies in the USA found no significant difference in abundance in clearcuts with woody debris retained or removed for eight of nine amphibian species, but the overall response of amphibians was more negative where woody debris was retained [843]. One randomized, replicated, controlled, before-and-after study in the USA found that compared to total clearcutting, leaving dead or wildlife trees did not result in higher abundances of salamanders [845]. Two studies in the USA found that compared to no harvesting, leaving dead or wildlife trees during clearcutting did not prevent a decrease in salamander abundance or change in species composition [845]. One replicated, site comparison study in the USA found that within clearcut forest, survival of juvenile amphibians was significantly higher in piles of woody debris than in open areas, and was similar in wood piles to unharvested forest [843]. One randomized, replicated, controlled study in the USA found that numbers of amphibian species and abundance were similar with removal or creation of dead trees within forest [845]. One replicated, controlled study in the USA found that migrating amphibians used clearcuts where woody debris was retained more than where it was removed [843]. There is no evidence for the effect of retaining patches of trees rather than clearcutting on amphibian populations [847].
summary_statements: A study in Canada found that red-legged frogs showed no significant movement toward retained tree patches.
In a Canadian study, red-legged frogs selected larger retained tree patches more and moved out of them less than they did smaller patches.
Studies in the USA and Indonesia found that the removal of coarse woody debris from standing forest did not decrease amphibian diversity or overall amphibian abundance.
One study found that removing coarse woody debris from a standing forest did reduce species richness.
Two studies in the USA found no significant difference in abundance for eight of nine amphibian species in clearcuts where woody debris was either retained or removed.
The overall response of amphibians was more negative in clearcuts where woody debris was retained.
A study in the USA found that leaving dead or wildlife trees did not result in higher abundances of salamanders when compared to total clearcutting.
Two studies in the USA found that leaving dead or wildlife trees during clearcutting did not prevent a decrease in salamander abundance when compared to no harvesting.
Two studies in the USA found that leaving dead or wildlife trees during clearcutting did not prevent a change in salamander species composition when compared to no harvesting.
Within a clearcut forest, the survival of juvenile amphibians was significantly higher in piles of woody debris than in open areas.
The survival of juvenile amphibians in wood piles within a clearcut forest was similar to their survival in unharvested forest.
A study in the USA found that the numbers of amphibian species and their abundance were similar whether dead trees were removed or created within a forest.
A study in the USA found that migrating amphibians used clearcuts where woody debris was retained more than where woody debris was removed.
There is no evidence for the effect on amphibian populations of retaining patches of trees as an alternative to clearcutting.

question_details.query: What are the documented benefits and potential negative impacts of releasing captive-bred or head-started toads into the wild?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Captive-bred toads released as tadpoles, juveniles or metamorphs have been found to establish populations in some cases (875, 873). In one instance, 70% of release sites were populated (875), and for Mallorcan midwife toads, breeding populations were established at 38% to 100% of sites (873). Head-starting amphibians has also been shown to establish or increase populations of frogs and toads. Nine out of ten studies found that head-started amphibians metamorphosed, survived their first season, winter or year, or bred successfully (881). Furthermore, four studies found that frog survival to metamorphosis and size at metamorphosis was greater, and time to metamorphosis was shorter in head-started individuals when compared to their wild counterparts (881).

However, there are also documented negative impacts. The release of captive-bred toads did not lead to established populations in one study (875). In Puerto Rico, the survival of released captive-bred Puerto Rican crested toads was low, with 25% being predated within just two days of release (875). For the Mallorcan midwife toad, a reintroduced population that was captive-bred was found to have reduced genetic diversity (873). Additionally, some studies on head-starting amphibians found that the release of metamorphs or adults did not prevent a frog population decline or establish a breeding toad population, with one study noting adult survival at a low rate of 1-17% over four years (881). In one Canadian study, young head-started leopard frogs were found to be smaller than those in the wild (881).
summary_statements: Captive-bred toads released as tadpoles, juveniles or metamorphs have been found to establish populations in some cases.
In one instance, 70% of release sites for captive-bred toads were populated.
For Mallorcan midwife toads, breeding populations were established at 38% to 100% of release sites.
Head-starting amphibians has been shown to establish or increase populations of frogs and toads.
Nine out of ten studies found that head-started amphibians metamorphosed, survived their first season, winter or year, or bred successfully.
Four studies found that frog survival to metamorphosis was greater in head-started individuals when compared to their wild counterparts.
Four studies found that size at metamorphosis was greater in head-started individuals when compared to their wild counterparts.
Four studies found that time to metamorphosis was shorter in head-started individuals when compared to their wild counterparts.
The release of captive-bred toads did not lead to established populations in one study.
In Puerto Rico, the survival of released captive-bred Puerto Rican crested toads was low.
In Puerto Rico, 25% of released captive-bred Puerto Rican crested toads were predated within just two days of release.
A reintroduced population of the Mallorcan midwife toad that was captive-bred was found to have reduced genetic diversity.
Some studies on head-starting amphibians found that the release of metamorphs or adults did not prevent a frog population decline.
Some studies on head-starting amphibians found that the release of metamorphs or adults did not establish a breeding toad population.
One study on head-starting amphibians noted adult survival at a low rate of 1-17% over four years.
In one Canadian study, young head-started leopard frogs were found to be smaller than leopard frogs in the wild.

question_details.query: What actions can be taken to provide or improve shelter and refuge habitats for amphibians?

summary_details.relevant_summary: There is no evidence for the effects of creating refuge areas in aquatic habitats on amphibian populations (813). Two replicated, controlled studies in the USA and Indonesia found that adding coarse woody debris to forest floors had no effect on the number of amphibian species or overall abundance, but had mixed effects on the abundance of individual species. One before-and-after study in Australia found that restoration that included reintroducing coarse woody debris to the forest floor increased frog species (772). One replicated, before-and-after study in the UK found that providing artificial hibernacula, along with other terrestrial habitat management, maintained populations of great crested newts, and another replicated study in the UK found that created hibernacula were used by common frogs and smooth newts, but not great crested newts. A third replicated study in the UK found four amphibian species close to hibernacula at two of three sites (759). Finally, two studies in New Zealand and the USA found that artificial refugia were used by translocated Hamilton's frogs and hellbenders, although few were used for breeding (772).
summary_statements: There is no evidence for the effects of creating refuge areas in aquatic habitats on amphibian populations.
Two replicated, controlled studies in the USA and Indonesia found that adding coarse woody debris to forest floors had no effect on the number of amphibian species or overall abundance.
Adding coarse woody debris to forest floors had mixed effects on the abundance of individual species.
One before-and-after study in Australia found that restoration that included reintroducing coarse woody debris to the forest floor increased frog species.
A replicated, before-and-after study in the UK found that providing artificial hibernacula, along with other terrestrial habitat management, maintained populations of great crested newts.
Another replicated study in the UK found that created hibernacula were used by common frogs and smooth newts.
The created hibernacula in a UK study were not used by great crested newts.
A third replicated study in the UK found four amphibian species close to hibernacula at two of three sites.
Two studies in New Zealand and the USA found that artificial refugia were used by translocated Hamilton's frogs and hellbenders.
Few of the artificial refugia were used for breeding by translocated Hamilton's frogs and hellbenders.

question_details.query: What factors have been found to influence the success of amphibian translocation projects?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Three global reviews and one replicated, before-and-after study in the USA found that 35 of 54 (65%) amphibian translocations resulted in established breeding populations or substantial recruitment to the adult population (854). One review found that translocations of over 1,000 animals were more successful, but that success was not related to the source of animals (wild or captive), life-stage, continent or reason for translocation (854). One before-and-after study in Denmark found that translocated garlic toads established breeding populations following pond restoration that included canopy removal (758). Seven studies in Austria, Denmark, Poland, the Netherlands and USA found that use or colonization of or reproductive success in created ponds was affected by pond age, permanence, vegetation cover, surrounding landscape, distance to existing ponds and presence of fish (869).
summary_statements: Three global reviews and one replicated, before-and-after study in the USA found that 35 of 54 (65%) amphibian translocations resulted in established breeding populations.
Thirty-five of 54 (65%) amphibian translocations in a set of studies resulted in substantial recruitment to the adult population.
One review found that translocations of over 1,000 animals were more successful.
One review found that the success of amphibian translocations was not related to the source of animals, whether wild or captive.
The success of amphibian translocations was not related to the life-stage of the animals, the continent, or the reason for translocation, according to one review.
A before-and-after study in Denmark found that translocated garlic toads established breeding populations following pond restoration that included canopy removal.
Seven studies found that the use or colonization of created ponds was affected by pond age, permanence, and vegetation cover.
Seven studies found that reproductive success in created ponds was affected by the surrounding landscape, distance to existing ponds, and the presence of fish.

question_details.query: In the USA, how do partial harvesting techniques like shelterwood, leave-tree, and group harvesting compare in their effects on salamander populations versus clearcutting?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
In the USA, shelterwood harvesting resulted in higher, similar, or initially higher and then similar salamander abundance compared to clearcutting (851). In contrast, three studies found that harvesting trees in small groups did not lead to higher amphibian or salamander abundance compared to clearcutting (844). However, a meta-analysis of 24 studies in North America indicated that partial harvesting, which includes shelterwood, group harvesting, and thinning, resulted in smaller reductions in salamander populations than clearcutting (851, 844, 852). When compared to no harvesting, both shelterwood harvesting and harvesting trees in small groups were found to decrease salamander abundance and alter species composition (851, 844). Two studies on thinning found higher amphibian abundance or a less negative overall response in thinned forests compared to clearcut forests (852).

In terms of reproductive effects, one study found that the proportion of female salamanders carrying eggs, the number of eggs per female, and the proportion of juveniles were similar or lower in plots with shelterwood harvesting compared to unharvested plots (851). Similarly, in plots where trees were harvested in groups, the proportion of females with eggs was similar to unharvested plots, while the proportion of eggs per female and juveniles were similar or lower (844).
summary_statements: In the USA, shelterwood harvesting resulted in higher salamander abundance compared to clearcutting.
In the USA, shelterwood harvesting resulted in salamander abundance that was similar to clearcutting.
In the USA, shelterwood harvesting resulted in initially higher and then similar salamander abundance compared to clearcutting.
Harvesting trees in small groups did not lead to higher amphibian abundance compared to clearcutting.
Harvesting trees in small groups did not lead to higher salamander abundance compared to clearcutting.
A meta-analysis in North America indicated that partial harvesting resulted in smaller reductions in salamander populations than clearcutting.
Partial harvesting includes shelterwood, group harvesting, and thinning.
Compared to no harvesting, shelterwood harvesting was found to decrease salamander abundance.
Compared to no harvesting, shelterwood harvesting was found to alter salamander species composition.
Compared to no harvesting, harvesting trees in small groups was found to decrease salamander abundance.
Compared to no harvesting, harvesting trees in small groups was found to alter salamander species composition.
Studies on thinning found higher amphibian abundance in thinned forests compared to clearcut forests.
Studies on thinning found a less negative overall response for amphibians in thinned forests compared to clearcut forests.
The proportion of female salamanders carrying eggs was similar or lower in plots with shelterwood harvesting compared to unharvested plots.
The number of eggs per female salamander was similar or lower in plots with shelterwood harvesting compared to unharvested plots.
The proportion of juvenile salamanders was similar or lower in plots with shelterwood harvesting compared to unharvested plots.
In plots where trees were harvested in groups, the proportion of females with eggs was similar to unharvested plots.
In plots where trees were harvested in groups, the proportion of eggs per female was similar or lower than in unharvested plots.
In plots where trees were harvested in groups, the proportion of juveniles was similar or lower than in unharvested plots.

question_details.query: What have been the observed effects of excluding livestock from ponds and streams on amphibian populations in the USA and UK?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Three replicated, site comparison studies in the USA found that excluding livestock from streams or ponds did not increase the number of amphibian species or their overall abundance (746). However, it did lead to an increase in larval abundance and the abundance of green frog metamorphs (746). Conversely, two of these studies found that the abundance of green frogs and/or American toads was higher in areas with grazing (746). A separate randomized, replicated, controlled, before-and-after study in the USA showed that excluding cattle from ponds did not lead to an increase in the number of eggs or the survival of larvae for Columbia spotted frogs (746). In the UK, a before-and-after study indicated that pond restoration, which included the exclusion of livestock, resulted in increased use of the pond by breeding natterjack toads (746).
summary_statements: Three replicated, site comparison studies in the USA found that excluding livestock from streams or ponds did not increase the number of amphibian species or their overall abundance.
Excluding livestock from streams or ponds did lead to an increase in larval abundance.
Excluding livestock from streams or ponds did lead to an increase in the abundance of green frog metamorphs.
Two replicated, site comparison studies in the USA found that the abundance of green frogs and/or American toads was higher in areas with grazing.
A randomized, replicated, controlled, before-and-after study in the USA showed that excluding cattle from ponds did not lead to an increase in the number of eggs for Columbia spotted frogs.
A randomized, replicated, controlled, before-and-after study in the USA showed that excluding cattle from ponds did not lead to an increase in the survival of larvae for Columbia spotted frogs.
In the UK, a before-and-after study indicated that pond restoration, which included the exclusion of livestock, resulted in increased use of the pond by breeding natterjack toads.

question_details.query: What design and placement factors are associated with the successful use of road tunnels by migrating amphibians?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
The successful use of road tunnels by migrating amphibians is associated with several design and placement factors. The use of culverts or tunnels as road crossings has been found to significantly decrease amphibian road deaths in six of seven studies (884). For these tunnels to be effective, they often need to be used in conjunction with barrier fencing to guide amphibians to the entrances (884). One study found that barriers need to be at least 0.6 m high to prevent some frog species from climbing over (756).

Several design characteristics of the tunnels themselves have been shown to affect their use by amphibians. Wider culverts were used more in three of six studies, while long culverts were avoided in one of two studies (884). The substrate within the tunnel is also a factor, with natural substrates being used more in three of six studies (884). Other factors that have been studied with mixed effects include lighting, the presence of water, entrance location, and tunnel climate (884). Certain designs have proven to be unsuitable, such as one-way tunnels with vertical entry chutes, which led to high mortality in common toads, and steel culverts, from which condensation deposits had very high metal concentrations (884). In one case, raising a road on a viaduct to restore connectivity between two wetlands also significantly decreased the deaths of migrating amphibians (840).
summary_statements: The successful use of road tunnels by migrating amphibians is associated with several design and placement factors.
The use of culverts or tunnels as road crossings has been found to significantly decrease amphibian road deaths.
For road tunnels to be effective, the tunnels often need to be used in conjunction with barrier fencing to guide amphibians to the entrances.
Barriers need to be at least 0.6 m high to prevent some frog species from climbing over.
Several design characteristics of road tunnels have been shown to affect their use by amphibians.
Wider culverts were used more by amphibians.
Long culverts were sometimes avoided by amphibians.
The substrate within an amphibian tunnel is a factor in its use.
Tunnels with natural substrates were used more by amphibians.
Factors that have been studied with mixed effects on amphibian tunnel use include lighting, the presence of water, entrance location, and tunnel climate.
One-way tunnels with vertical entry chutes are an unsuitable design that has led to high mortality in common toads.
Steel culverts are an unsuitable design because condensation deposits from the culverts had very high metal concentrations.
Raising a road on a viaduct to restore connectivity between two wetlands significantly decreased the deaths of migrating amphibians.

question_details.query: In US forests, how do mechanical and herbicide-based methods for controlling understory vegetation compare in their effects on amphibians?

summary_details.relevant_summary: In US forests, one randomized, replicated, controlled study found that the number of amphibian species, but not the overall amphibian abundance, was significantly higher in plots where understory vegetation was mechanically removed compared to plots with no removal (781). In contrast, three studies in the USA, including two that were randomized, replicated, and controlled, found that using herbicides to remove understory vegetation had either no effect or some negative effects on amphibian abundance (778).
summary_statements: In US forests, one study found the number of amphibian species was significantly higher in plots where understory vegetation was mechanically removed compared to plots with no removal.
In US forests, one study found that the overall amphibian abundance was not significantly higher in plots where understory vegetation was mechanically removed compared to plots with no removal.
Three studies in the USA found that using herbicides to remove understory vegetation had either no effect or some negative effects on amphibian abundance.

question_details.query: What legal and regulatory actions are available to protect wild amphibian populations from threats like development and trade?

summary_details.relevant_summary: One review found that legislation to reduce trade in two frog species led to the recovery of over-exploited populations (785). A study in South Africa noted an increase in permits issued for scientific and educational use of amphibians from 1987 to 1990 (785). Conversely, three reviews in the Netherlands and the UK found that legal protection of amphibian species was not effective in safeguarding populations during development (779). Two reviews in the UK also reported that the number of great crested newt mitigation licences issued over a 10-year period rose to over 600 in England and Wales (779).
summary_statements: Legislation to reduce trade in two frog species led to the recovery of over-exploited populations.
In South Africa, permits issued for the scientific and educational use of amphibians increased from 1987 to 1990.
In the Netherlands and the UK, legal protection of amphibian species was not effective in safeguarding populations during development.
The number of great crested newt mitigation licences issued over a 10-year period rose to over 600 in England and Wales.

question_details.query: For natterjack toad conservation in the UK, what are the documented benefits and negative side effects of adding lime to ponds?

summary_details.relevant_summary: One before-and-after study in the UK showed that adding limestone to ponds led to the establishment of one of three translocated natterjack toad populations, and another UK study found that species-specific habitat management including the addition of limestone increased natterjack toad populations [748]. Adding limestone to ponds was also found to have temporarily increased breeding by natterjack toads in one UK before-and-after study, and resulted in metamorphosis of natterjack toads at two of three sites [748]. However, two before-and-after studies in the UK, one of which was controlled, revealed that the addition of limestone to ponds resulted in high tadpole mortality and pond abandonment by natterjack toads [748].
summary_statements: In a UK study, adding limestone to ponds led to the establishment of one of three translocated natterjack toad populations.
A UK study found that species-specific habitat management including the addition of limestone increased natterjack toad populations.
Adding limestone to ponds was found to have temporarily increased breeding by natterjack toads in one UK study.
The addition of limestone to ponds resulted in the metamorphosis of natterjack toads at two of three sites.
Two before-and-after studies in the UK revealed that the addition of limestone to ponds resulted in high tadpole mortality.
Two before-and-after studies in the UK revealed that the addition of limestone to ponds resulted in pond abandonment by natterjack toads.

question_details.query: What is the state of evidence on creating or restoring terrestrial habitat connectivity, such as through hedgerows, for amphibian populations?

summary_details.relevant_summary: A before-and-after study in Australia found that retaining native vegetation corridors maintained populations of eight of 13 frog species over 20 years [853]. A before-and-after study in Italy found that restoring connectivity between two wetlands by raising a road on a viaduct, significantly decreased deaths of migrating amphibians [840].
summary_statements: A before-and-after study in Australia found that retaining native vegetation corridors maintained populations of eight of 13 frog species over 20 years.
A before-and-after study in Italy found that restoring connectivity between two wetlands by raising a road on a viaduct, significantly decreased deaths of migrating amphibians.

question_details.query: To manage chytridiomycosis in captive amphibians, what are the most and least beneficial treatment strategies?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Based on the available information, several treatment strategies for chytridiomycosis in captive amphibians have been studied with varying success. Antifungal treatments have been found to be effective in many cases, with twelve out of sixteen studies showing they cured or increased the survival of amphibians with the disease (882). Specifically, the fungicide itraconazole was effective at curing amphibians in six of eight studies (882). Additionally, temperature treatment has shown promise, with four out of five studies demonstrating that increasing the enclosure or water temperature to 30–37°C for over 16 hours cured frogs and toads of chytridiomycosis (770).

However, these treatments are not always successful. In four studies, antifungal treatments did not cure the disease but only reduced infection levels or had mixed results (882). Furthermore, some fungicides were found to cause death or other negative side effects in amphibians in six studies (882). One study found that itraconazole only reduced infection levels, and another reported mixed effects (882). Temperature treatment also has its limitations, as one study found that heat treatment did not cure northern leopard frogs (770). Lastly, a study on wild midwife toads found that treating them with a fungicide, in conjunction with pond drying, only reduced infection levels and did not eradicate the chytridiomycosis (767).
summary_statements: Several treatment strategies for chytridiomycosis in captive amphibians have been studied with varying success.
Antifungal treatments have been found to be effective in many cases of chytridiomycosis.
Studies have shown antifungal treatments cured or increased the survival of amphibians with chytridiomycosis.
The fungicide itraconazole was effective at curing amphibians with chytridiomycosis.
Temperature treatment for chytridiomycosis has shown promise.
Increasing an enclosure or water temperature to 30–37°C for over 16 hours cured frogs and toads of chytridiomycosis.
Antifungal and temperature treatments for chytridiomycosis are not always successful.
In some studies, antifungal treatments did not cure chytridiomycosis but only reduced infection levels or had mixed results.
Some fungicides were found to cause death or other negative side effects in amphibians.
In one study, the fungicide itraconazole only reduced infection levels of chytridiomycosis.
Another study reported that the fungicide itraconazole had mixed effects in treating chytridiomycosis.
Temperature treatment for chytridiomycosis has limitations.
Heat treatment did not cure northern leopard frogs of chytridiomycosis.
Treating wild midwife toads with a fungicide, in conjunction with pond drying, only reduced infection levels and did not eradicate the chytridiomycosis.

question_details.query: What are the general outcomes of releasing captive-bred toads, including species like the Mallorcan midwife toad?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Two of three studies in Denmark, Sweden, and the USA found that releasing captive-bred toads as tadpoles, juveniles, or metamorphs established populations, with one study finding success at 70% of sites (875). However, another study reported that populations were not established using this method (875). For the Mallorcan midwife toad, three studies in Mallorca found that releasing captive-bred individuals as tadpoles, toadlets, or adults established breeding populations at 38% to 100% of sites (873).

Survival rates can be low, as seen in two Puerto Rican studies where captive-bred crested toads had low survival, and 25% were predated within two days of release (875). In contrast, a review of ten studies on head-started amphibians found that in nine cases, they tended to survive the first season or year and bred successfully (881). Head-starting amphibians has been found to increase populations of toads in some cases, though one study found it did not establish a breeding toad population (881). A study on a reintroduced captive-bred toad population in the UK noted that predator defences were maintained, but there was a reduction in genetic diversity (873).
summary_statements: Two of three studies in Denmark, Sweden, and the USA found that releasing captive-bred toads as tadpoles, juveniles, or metamorphs established populations.
One study found success at establishing populations of captive-bred toads at 70% of release sites.
Another study reported that populations of toads were not established by releasing captive-bred individuals.
For the Mallorcan midwife toad, three studies in Mallorca found that releasing captive-bred individuals as tadpoles, toadlets, or adults established breeding populations.
The release of captive-bred Mallorcan midwife toads established breeding populations at 38% to 100% of sites.
Survival rates for released captive-bred toads can be low.
Two Puerto Rican studies found that captive-bred crested toads had low survival.
In two Puerto Rican studies, 25% of released captive-bred crested toads were predated within two days of release.
A review of ten studies on head-started amphibians found that in nine cases, the amphibians tended to survive the first season or year and bred successfully.
Head-starting amphibians has been found to increase populations of toads in some cases.
One study found head-starting amphibians did not establish a breeding toad population.
A study on a reintroduced captive-bred toad population in the UK noted that predator defences were maintained.
A study on a reintroduced captive-bred toad population in the UK noted a reduction in genetic diversity.

question_details.query: For road mitigation projects, what design factors are associated with the success or failure of tunnels and culverts for amphibian passage?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Thirty-two studies evaluated the effectiveness of installing culverts or tunnels as road crossings for amphibians (884). Six of seven studies found that installing culverts or tunnels significantly decreased amphibian road deaths, with one study noting this was true only when barrier fencing was also installed (884). Fifteen of twenty-four studies found that amphibians used culverts or tunnels (884). The use of these passages was affected by several design factors. In some studies, wider culverts were used more, while long culverts were avoided (884). Natural substrates were used more than artificial ones (884). The effects of lighting and the presence of water on usage were mixed (884). Entrance location and tunnel climate were also found to be influencing factors in one study each (884). Conversely, certain designs were found to be unsuitable; for instance, one-way tunnels with vertical entry chutes caused high mortality in common toads, and condensation from steel culverts was found to have high concentrations of metal (884). Some studies also reported low usage rates (less than 10%) or no usage at all (884). Even with culverts, one study noted that thousands of amphibians were still killed on the road (884).
summary_statements: Thirty-two studies evaluated the effectiveness of installing culverts or tunnels as road crossings for amphibians.
Six of seven studies found that installing culverts or tunnels significantly decreased amphibian road deaths.
One study noted that amphibian road deaths decreased only when barrier fencing was also installed with culverts or tunnels.
Fifteen of twenty-four studies found that amphibians used culverts or tunnels.
The use of culverts or tunnels by amphibians was affected by several design factors.
In some studies, wider culverts were used more by amphibians.
Long culverts were avoided by amphibians in some studies.
Natural substrates within passages were used more than artificial ones.
The effects of lighting on the usage of passages by amphibians were mixed.
The effects of the presence of water on the usage of passages by amphibians were mixed.
In one study, the entrance location of a passage was found to be an influencing factor for amphibian use.
In one study, the tunnel climate was found to be an influencing factor for amphibian use.
Certain passage designs were found to be unsuitable for amphibians.
One-way tunnels with vertical entry chutes caused high mortality in common toads.
Condensation from steel culverts was found to have high concentrations of metal.
Some studies reported low usage rates (less than 10%) of passages by amphibians.
Some studies reported no usage of passages by amphibians at all.
One study noted that even with the presence of culverts, thousands of amphibians were still killed on the road.
